title: Improper input validation in projects leads to fully deny access to project resources
vulnerability_information:
#INTRODUCTION

**Accounts used to search for this vulnerability:**
- **id:** â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ **email:**â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ
- **id:** â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ **email:** â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

**Most of the requests made to test the vulnerability were made with the "X-hackerone:  a_d_a_m"  header**

**IP used:**
â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ / â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

**Endpoint URL:**
https://fr.semrush.com/projects/api/projects/tags/PROJECT_ID/?key=API_KEY

#EXPLOITATION
**Description of Security Issue:**

According to SEMrush documentation:
>Semrush Projects allow you to set up 11 different tools analyzing all aspects of a business's online visibility.

As shown below these projects can include tags:
{F1343556}

The problem stems from the fact that the input which contains the name of the tag is not validated correctly, an attacker has the possibility of setting the name of a tag to null, which is contrary to the logic of the application. Giving the value null to a tag name causes a critical bug in the front-end. If a person has a tag in their project list that has a null name, then the person will no longer be able to manage their projects, see their project list or access a project. The victim does not even have the option to delete the project with the sabotaged tag, since he can no longer manage his projects. A blank page will appear as shown in the video below:

{F1343572}

*However, this is not a security issue. For this to be considered as such, a vector would have to be found that would allow an attacker to impact other users.*

According to the documentation:
>Project sharing is also available to make collaboration between teams and agencies easy.

Through this tool I have found 2 ways to impact an external user:

- The first is to have been invited by someone to a project with "can edit" rights. Thus, the attacker will be able to modify the labels of the project and impact the owner and all the participants of the project. (with interaction and privileges)

{F1343606}

*Steps needed to reproduce 1st bug:*
{F1343639}

- The second way is to invite someone with their email to a project that we created with a sabotaged tag, so our project will be directly present in the victim's project list and will be directly impacted without interaction of the victim.  (**without interaction and privileges**)

*Steps needed to reproduce 2nd bug:*
{F1343659}

#RESOLUTION

In my opinion, the best solution would be to validate the type of the tag names entered in the request (forbid the null type).






The type of the bug is "Improper Input Validation (CWE-20)" but I couldn't find it in the list of weakness, it's weird given that it is available in other programs when I make a report. Given that I did not find any other type of weakness in the list which could come close to what I found, I didn't put the name of the weakness.Can you try to put it if you can ?

## Impact

**There is total loss of availability, resulting in the attacker being able to fully deny access to resources in the impacted component without any interaction from the victim.**

**exploitation scenarios:**
- We can take the email addresses of the most important semrush clients (agencies, companies, etc.) and paralyze all their projects

*From what I heard in the documentation, agencies working on online visibility use SEMrush with this tool to have a project for each client, we can imagine that a malicious person can impact agencies specializing in online visibility by inviting their email address to a sabotaged project.
This will have the effect of preventing these agencies from accessing their clients' projects and managing them just with their email address.*

- A guest of a project (employee / client / ...) with editing rights can paralyze all projects of the owner and collaborators on the project

To find the email of an individual/company that you are targeting, *you can search on google or on social networks/request the email from the company by inventing x or y reason/we can also know the target's email address for other reasons (former employee / collaborator, close to the company, etc ...). Another very good tool: hunter.io, which allows you to extract email addresses from a domain name.*

{F1343710}

Once a wordlist of victims' email addresses has been created, an attacker can format these emails in json format to invite them to the sabotaged project.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, we are investigating this.
Hi @a_d_a_m , we've pushed your report to the appropriate team to evaluate the risk level. Once we get feedback we'll let you know. Please keep in mind that the severity might be changed
Thank you for your feedback!

Hi @a_d_a_m , your report was pushed to appropriate team and I will triage it. With the dev team we decided that the severity of this issue is medium - this only affect frontend of the app - no corruption to the data. Moreover you need to get the list valid emails.
Thanks for making our service safer!

Hello @katereena_m ðŸ™‚,
I don't understand the severity calculation, it's not just the data corruption factor that comes into the severity calculation. There is also the factor of confidentiality, integrity and availability. In this case, it is the avaibility factor that I think is noticeably high, even if it concerns the front-end as this is what the SEMrush client will be handling. If the front-end doesn't work then the client can't do anything. There is total loss of availability, resulting in the attacker being able to fully deny access to resources in the impacted component without any interaction from the victim.
For email, this data is not secret and complicated to retrieve using the tools I mentioned in my report or by many possible scenarios(by being invited to a project regardless of our rights we have access to the owner's email, etc...).
I hope you will understand my point of view!
Thank you :) !

Hi adam,  cvss scoring calculation is quite rough and covers potential severity. But each case depends on different factors.
In our program we ask researchers to refrain from spamming and social engineering our employees (whose emails you showed on a screenshot) and also from techniques leading to degradation of service. Your report is describing both cases.
However, we accept this issue as a parsing problem on a frontend. Hope, this clarifies our decision.

Hi @katereena_m,
I think I have been misunderstood:
>In our program we ask researchers to refrain from spamming and social engineering our employees (whose emails you showed on a screenshot)

**I did not at any time violate your Program Policy. During my bug research I did not at any time contact a SEMrush employee.**

Also the vulnerability does not require spamming and social engineering, so how could I have described this in my report?

I used the following photo F1343710 to show you the way in which the tool can be used by an attacker. If I used "semrush.com" as the domain name, it is because it is the first thing that came to mind since I am testing on your program. It was only for the purpose of demonstrating the tool.

>and also from techniques leading to degradation of service.

I reread your program and the only thing I found is:
"While researching, we'd like to ask you to refrain from: Denial of service."

According to cloudflare:
>A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is a type of cyber attack in which a malicious actor aims to render a computer or other device unavailable to its intended users by interrupting the device's normal functioning. DoS attacks typically function by overwhelming or flooding a targeted machine with requests until normal traffic is unable to be processed, resulting in denial-of-service to addition users. A DoS attack is characterized by using a single computer to launch the attack.

The bug does not overload the server and is targeted on the victims chosen by the attacker.

H @a_d_a_m , I didn't mean that you disregard the policy. My idea was again about the factors that might affect the severity
My point is that the attack is complex, depends on how many valid emails an attacker can obtain and how. 
Creating a real PoC in this case means performing some social engineering, like you described for example:
"request the email from the company by inventing x or y reason/we can also know the target's email address for other reasons (former employee / collaborator, close to the company, etc ...). "
Real PoC will rise the severity of course, but you will need to perform it against our rules.

Moreover, I forgot to mention that the dev team took into consideration business risks - they are now in the final stage of developing the new code base for this functionality. This will be released in 2 weeks. And this issue does not present there. So they does not evaluate this issue as critical or high.

Thank you for the clarifications!
Have a nice day katereena

Hi,
would you agree to pass me a promo code please?

Hello, @a_d_a_m!
Here's the promo -â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ 
You have one week to activate it and it will last for 2 weeks. Also, you can activate it (during this week) for multiple accounts for testing IDOR.
Here you can see a brief description of Business plan's features - https://www.semrush.com/prices/#table.
Thank you  @wshuwll =) !

The type of the bug is "Improper Input Validation (CWE-20)" but I couldn't find it in the list of weakness, it's weird given that it is available in other programs when I make a report. Given that I did not find any other type of weakness in the list which could come close to what I found, I didn't put the name of the weakness.Can you try to put it if you can ?
Thank you!
hi @a_d_a_m , I don't see it either. Will are trying to resolve this issue and I'll get back to you once I have updates on that.
By the way, can you please check the fix?

Hello @katereena_m !
Yes I can confirm the fix
Thank you for the feedback =)
Thank you!

Hello ! =)
Would you agree to disclose the report?
If you are, do you think it would be possible not to redact the report?

Hi @a_d_a_m , yes we can disclose this report. I' ll just need to redact IP, internal ids and your personal email addresses.

By the way, the issue with cwe was fixed, so it's properly assigned now

Hello @katereena_m ,
Thank you for the feed back !
